Today, the White House issued another plan to cope with a flu pandemic if and when it arrives.
Last November, President Bush released a broad strategic plan.
This one is designed to implement that strategy.
The new plan contains a more specific to do list for government agencies and for the private sector.
But it also contains more warnings about how bad things could get during a worst-case flu pandemic.
It says local communities should not count on the federal government to provide the kind of aid it does during other natural disasters.
It says medical care would have to rationed, including drugs, vaccine and ventilators to help very sick people breathe.
And it also warns of civil disorder that could overwhelm local police.
Reporters at the White House asked Frances Townsend, the president's Homeland Security Advisor, how the government would avoid chaos.
We deal with the science of this.

Well, as Frances Townsend said at the White House, it's planning for a worst- case nightmare, like the pandemic that killed maybe 50 million people around the world in 1918.
And, you know, it's not to say that will ever happen, or anytime soon.
The Asian bird flu that people are concerned about right now might not ever go pandemic.
But if, or rather when, some brand new flu virus does touch off a pandemic, then federal planners say it would be impossible to stop at our borders.

The plan does envision closing some international airports at the outset and screening some, you know, screening foreign air travelers, but that's just really to slow things down a little bit and buy some time.
Once the pandemic virus got in, the planners say 100 million Americans could get sick, 10 million could need hospital care, as many as 2 million might die.
It might not happen that way, but the administration has decided that it's prudent to plan for it.

It's pretty blunt.
